issues.title: Can 'critical' be encoded as a single bit?
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Or do we need to encode three options
- Absent
- Present and false
- Present and true

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
In that case the int n could be encodes as 
3n + crit, where crit= 0,1,2

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Reading RFC 5280:
 
   Extension  ::=  SEQUENCE  {
        extnID      OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
        critical    BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
        extnValue   OCTET STRING
                    -- contains the DER encoding of an ASN.1 value
                    -- corresponding to the extension type identified
                    -- by extnID
        }
 
Implementers should note that the DER encoding of SET or SEQUENCE components whose value is the DEFAULT omit the component from the encoded certificate or CRL.
 
My understanding reading RFC 5280 is that DER never explicitly send critical = FALSE. So the information can be encoded with a single bit.

issues.title: EUI-64 optimizations
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Should we optimize for any specific EUI-64 format. Are EUI-64 of the forms 
xx-xx-xx-FF-FE-xx-xx-xx
xx-xx-xx-FF-FF-xx-xx-xx

common in X.509 certificates? If so the most common form should be encoded to a byte string of 6 bytes. If both are somewhat common, the second most common could be encoded as a byte string of 7 bytes.

EUI-48, MAC-48, and 48-bit MAC address are all somewhat different. Mappings of EUI-48 and MAC-48 are deprecated according to IEEE so any such mapping should not be encouraged. Unclear if mapping from 48-bit MAC address is deprecated.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address:

To convert a MAC-48 into an EUI-64, copy the organizationally unique identifier (OUI), append the two octets FF-FF and then copy the organization-specified extension identifier. To convert an EUI-48 into an EUI-64, the same process is used, but the sequence inserted is FF-FE.[5] In both cases, the process could be trivially reversed when necessary. Organizations issuing EUI-64s were cautioned against issuing identifiers that could be confused with these forms.

IEEE says that:
https://standards.ieee.org/content/dam/ieee-standards/standards/web/documents/tutorials/eui.pdf

The subtle difference between MAC-48 and EUI-48 was not well understood, so the term EUI-48 is now used for both uses, and the term MAC-48 identifier is now obsolete. . (The IEEE RAC is not aware of any cases, but if MAC-48 is used as the name for any 48-bit MAC address, then EUI-48 is not the appropriate replacement term for MAC-48, as EUI-48 only refers to individual,
universally/globally unique network addresses.)

Mapping an EUI-48 to an EUI-64 is deprecated. The mapping is described here
for historical reasons.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Decision to just try to encode what is used out in the wild. common names with the format "HH-HH-HH-HH-HH-HH-HH-HH" and "HH-HH-HH-FF-FE-HH-HH-HH" are not optimized

issues.title: EUI-64 in certificates and MAC Address randomization
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
EUI-64 is often created from 48-bit MAC addresses. Having a fixed MAC address goes against the current trend of MAC Address randomization.

- Should IoT devices always use EUI-64 in certificates?
- Should the EUI-64 be derived from the 48-bit MAC addresses?
- Should IoT devices use MAC Address randomization?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Note: According to the IEEE guidelines, the first four digits of the organizationally assigned identifier (i.e., the first four digits of the extension identifier) portion of an EUI-64 “shall not be FFFE16 or FFFF16” (i.e., EUI-64 identifiers of the form ccccccFFFEeeeeee and ccccccFFFFeeeeee are not allowed) – this is to support the encapsulation of EUI-48 (FFFE16) and MAC-48 (FFFF16) values into EUI-64 values (though now the encapsulation is deprecated).

Other identifiers

issues.title: Compress character strings?
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Printablestring is a small subset of ASCII. Printablestring can only contain 74 characters. If they are uniformly distributed, this can be endoded using 6.2 bits. If they are not uniformly distributed the string can be even more compressed.

The utf8string can probably be compressed with a similar amount assuming they mostly cointain ASCII

issues.title: MUST and SHOULD inRFC 5280
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Implementations SHOULD be prepared to accept any version certificate.

* locality (SHOULD), is used on the web

MUST be prepared to receive the domainComponent attribute

A certificate MUST NOT include more
   than one instance of a particular extension. 

Conforming CAs MUST support key identifiers (Sections 4.2.1.1 and
   4.2.1.2), basic constraints (Section 4.2.1.9), key usage (Section
   4.2.1.3), and certificate policies (Section 4.2.1.4) extensions.  If
   the CA issues certificates with an empty sequence for the subject
   field, the CA MUST support the subject alternative name extension

  At a minimum, applications conforming to this profile MUST recognize
   the following extensions: key usage (Section 4.2.1.3), certificate
   policies (Section 4.2.1.4), subject alternative name (Section
   4.2.1.6), basic constraints (Section 4.2.1.9), name constraints
   (Section 4.2.1.10), policy constraints (Section 4.2.1.11), extended
   key usage (Section 4.2.1.12), and inhibit anyPolicy (Section
   4.2.1.14).

   In addition, applications conforming to this profile SHOULD recognize
   the authority and subject key identifier (Sections 4.2.1.1 and
   4.2.1.2) and policy mappings (Section 4.2.1.5) extensions.

issues.title: Add text on nativly signed certificates

issues.title: unwrapped CBOR tag number 1 for validity?
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
If CBOR encoders and decoders already support unix time it removed one of the reasons to not use unix time. 

- unit time does not support leap second, but we could probably live without.
- how to differentiate between utctime and generalizedtime? RFC 5280 states that UTCtime shall be used before 2050 but this is not always followed (e.g. Brazil has a cetificate policy stating that GeneralizedTime is always used). Do we care about implementations breaking RFC 5280?
- If we ignore leap seconds and mandate following rfc 5280 the encoding size of the current unwrapped biguing and a unwrapped tag 1 would be the same.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: CDDL for unwrapped unix time is ~time

issues.title: Attribute character string types and emailAddress attribute type
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Is there any need to support TeletexString, BMPString, or UniversalString, or IA5String? Neither should appear in new certificates.

Is there any need to support emailAddress attribute type?


   attribute [RFC2985].  The attribute value for emailAddress is of type
   IA5String to permit inclusion of the character '@', which is not part
   of the PrintableString character set.  emailAddress attribute values
   are not case-sensitive (e.g., "subscriber@example.com" is the same as
   "SUBSCRIBER@EXAMPLE.COM").

RFC 5280 states that:

CAs
   conforming to this profile MUST use either the PrintableString or
   UTF8String encoding of DirectoryString, with two exceptions.  When
   CAs have previously issued certificates with issuer fields with
   attributes encoded using TeletexString, BMPString, or
   UniversalString, then the CA MAY continue to use these encodings of
   the DirectoryString to preserve backward compatibility.  Also, new
   CAs that are added to a domain where existing CAs issue certificates
   with issuer fields with attributes encoded using TeletexString,
   BMPString, or UniversalString MAY encode attributes that they share
   with the existing CAs using the same encodings as the existing CAs
   use.


      (c)  TeletexString, BMPString, and UniversalString are included
           for backward compatibility, and SHOULD NOT be used for
           certificates for new subjects.  However, these types MAY be
           used in certificates where the name was previously
           established, including cases in which a new certificate is
           being issued to an existing subject or a certificate is being
           issued to a new subject where the attributes being encoded
           have been previously established in certificates issued to
           other subjects.  Certificate users SHOULD be prepared to
           receive certificates with these types.

   Legacy implementations exist where an electronic mail address is
   embedded in the subject distinguished name as an emailAddress
   attribute [RFC2985].  The attribute value for emailAddress is of type
   IA5String to permit inclusion of the character '@', which is not part
   of the PrintableString character set.  emailAddress attribute values
   are not case-sensitive (e.g., "subscriber@example.com" is the same as
   "SUBSCRIBER@EXAMPLE.COM").

issues.title: Decide which optimizations are worth having
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
- I removed the optimization to skip the outer array in subject and issuer.

- "If subjectAltName contains exactly one dNSName, the array and the int are omitted and extensionValue is the dNSName encoded as a CBOR text string." This saves 2 byte

- The EUI-64 optimization saves 17 bytes and should definitly be kept.

- The optimization for keyusage saves 2 bytes.

- The optimization for the special case utf8string common name saves 3 bytes.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: I'd vote to ditch the subjectAltName optimization (and the first which you already removed) and keep the rest.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Conclusion for now is to keep the remaining optimizations.

issues.title: Compression examples with Brotli
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
It seems like real world use of TLS certificate compression will likely use Brotli.
https://github.com/google/brotli

https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5696925844111360
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1548723

I think we should provide example with Brotli instead of zlib.

Certificate (chain) sizes is a real problem also in many non-IoT deployments.

https://www.fastly.com/blog/quic-handshake-tls-compression-certificates-extension-study
https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-emu-eaptlscert-08

I would like to see a matrix of example compressions:

                                            No comp            Brotli             CBOR              CBOR+Brotli

RFC7925
ietf.org chain
tools.ietf.org chain

issues.title: Signaure and Public Key Algorithms (Figure 8 and 9)
issues.author: StefanHri
issues.body:
I noticed few things regarding figure 8 and 9 which I don't understand:

1) What is the purpose and difference between Figure 8 and 9?
2) When we use static DH authentication with EDHOC the public static DH key can be put in a certificate. Are Figures 8,9 showing the possible algorithms for static DH keys also?
3) The names in these tables are somehow inconsistent. Some begin with id (e.g. id-ecdsa-with-shake256) and some are without id (ecdsa-with-SHA256). Is this wanted?
4) I think some of these algorithms are not suitable for IoT e.g. RSA.
5) I am not familiar with all of the algorithms and I think many of the readers are also not, therefore I think it will be good to have some table showing at least the key lengths. The performance of those algorithms on constrained IoT devices needs also to be made comparable in some form.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Hi,

1. X.509 (RFC5280) has different public key and signature algorithms. This follows X.509. Some Object Identifiers (OIDs) are used for both public keys and signatures, while other are restricted to one of the uses.

2. Yes, Figure 9 show all public key algorithms. When used in EDHOC with static DH authentication, then one of the following algorithms would typically be used in the certificate

```
+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
|     1 | Name:        EC Public Key (Weierstraß) with secp256r1    |
|       | OID:         1.2.840.10045.2.1                            |
|       | Parameters:  namedCurve = secp256r1 (1.2.840.10045.3.1.7) |
|       | DER:         30 13 06 07 2A 86 48 CE 3D 02 01 06 08 2A 86 |
|       |              48 CE 3D 03 01 07                            |
|       | Comments:    Point compressed subjectPublicKey            |
+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
|     2 | Name:        EC Public Key (Weierstraß) with secp384r1    |
|       | OID:         1.2.840.10045.2.1                            |
|       | Parameters:  namedCurve = secp384r1 (1.3.132.0.34)        |
|       | DER:         30 10 06 07 2A 86 48 CE 3D 02 01 06 05 2B 81 |
|       |              04 00 22                                     |
|       | Comments:    Point compressed subjectPublicKey            |
+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
|     8 | Name:        X25519 (Montgomery)                          |
|       | OID:         1.3.101.110                                  |
|       | Parameters:  Absent                                       |
|       | DER:         30 05 06 03 2B 65 6E                         |
|       | Comments:                                                 |
+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
```

3. The names used in the version you read follows the identifiers used when registering the algorithms. The inconsistencies are following X.509 and are intentional (but not wanted). The registration of OIDs is very decentralised and a bit messy. The latest version on Github completely changes the figures to make then eaasier to understand as well as better specified.

4. Yes, several of the algorithms are not suitable for constrained IoT.

5. That's a good idea. I think we could have some section where these things are discussed on a high level in an informal way.

issues.title: CBOR Sequence parsing in libraries
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Do the format need to be adjusted to make implementation with some CBOR encoders and decoders easier?

Laruance Lundblade: Some CBOR decoders don’t allow access a sub-part of the encoded CBOR so it can be input into the signature algorithm. Suggest to wrap TBSCertificate in a byte string

Stefan Hristozov : Easy to calculate offset with tinycbor and his own Rust implementation

Joel Höglund: Small on the wire size is important.

Carsten Bormann: One valid use of CBOR is to prefix a single CBOR data item to a byte sequence (not itself packaged as a CBOR string). 

Wrapping TBSCertificate in a byte string would add 2-3 additional bytes.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Discussion at interim 2020-12-16 was that this is a tradeoff without a clear answer. Should be evaluated at a later point.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Currently no consensus, closing! (Can be reopened if there are new input.)

issues.title: Certificate Signing Request (CSR)
issues.author: StefanHri
issues.body: Does it make sense to have CBOR encoded CSRs? For example, if we have a constrained IoT device communicating over a constrained network the device may want to get a certificate from a remote CA by sending a CSR. What needs to be contained in the CSR and how should it be encoded?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
How about this:
https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-selander-ace-coap-est-oscore-04.html#name-enrollment-re-enrollment-of

One example showing how EDHOC could be used with CBOR encoded CSR is shown in slide 3 of
https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/109/materials/slides-109-ace-draft-selander-ace-ake-authz-01.pdf

comments.author: StefanHri
comments.body: This is exactly what I am looking for. I think it will be good to have a short section in this document about CSR encoding and a CSR test vector.

comments.author: StefanHri
comments.body:
[1] says: 
The essential information fields for the CA to verify are the following:
* Information about the subject, here condensed to the subject common name,
* subject public key, and
* signature made by the subject private key.

However, according to [2] a certificate signature is calculated over the following fields:
* cborCertificateType,
* certificateSerialNumber,
* issuer,
* validityNotBefore,
* validityNotAfter,
* subject (subject common name),
* subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm,
* subjectPublicKey,
* extensions,
* issuerSignatureAlgorithm,

Is it not necessary to include in the CSR also: 
* cborCertificateType,
* validityNotBefore,
* validityNotAfter,
* subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm,
* extensions,
If those fields are not included in the CSR, how the CA can know them? Or those fields are negotiated out of band?

In this way the CSR will contain all fields of TBSCertificate except:
* certificateSerialNumber,
* issuer,
* issuerSignatureAlgorithm,
which are known to the CA? 

[1]: https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-selander-ace-coap-est-oscore-04.html#name-enrollment-re-enrollment-of
[2]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-mattsson-cose-cbor-cert-compress-05#section-3.1

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
I think the common case is that the CA is the entity deciding the values for validity and extensions. But I agree that the info on the subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm must be communicated somehow.

//Joel

The essential information fields for the CA to verify are the following:

  *   Information about the subject, here condensed to the subject common name,
  *   subject public key, and
  *   signature made by the subject private key.

However, according to 2<https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdatatracker.ietf.org%2Fdoc%2Fhtml%2Fdraft-mattsson-cose-cbor-cert-compress-05%23section-3.1&data=04%7C01%7Cjoel.hoglund%40ri.se%7C01c87289a4e6441c505b08d8a9df1cfd%7C5a9809cf0bcb413a838a09ecc40cc9e8%7C0%7C0%7C637446123480923853%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000&sdata=jFq4723DfSiVTiaq%2FI%2Fg8n88uHnoJzZpokEckUvfCAM%3D&reserved=0> a certificate signature is calculated over the following fields:

  *   cborCertificateType,
  *   certificateSerialNumber,
  *   issuer,
  *   validityNotBefore,
  *   validityNotAfter,
  *   subject (subject common name),
  *   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm,
  *   subjectPublicKey,
  *   extensions,
  *   issuerSignatureAlgorithm,

Is it not necessary to include in the CSR also:

  *   cborCertificateType,
  *   validityNotBefore,
  *   validityNotAfter,
  *   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm,
  *   extensions,
If those fields are not included in the CSR, how the CA can know them? Or those fields are negotiated out of band?

In this way the CSR will contain all fields of TBSCertificate except:

  *   certificateSerialNumber,
  *   issuer,
  *   issuerSignatureAlgorithm,
which are known to the CA?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I quickly made CDDL for CSR based on the C509 draft

```
C509CertificationRequest = [
   TBSCertificationRequest,
   subjectPoPValue: any,
]

; The elements of the following group are to be used in a CBOR Sequence:
TBSCertificationRequest = (
   c509CertificationRequestType: int,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   attributes: [ * Attribute ],
   subjectPoPAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
)

Attribute = ( attributeType: int, attributeValue: any )
```
I think there is agreement to add this, so I will make a commit with a new section so that we have something to work from.

The format above rfc2986. Most definitions can just be reused from draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert

- I don't think there is any reason to have a CBOR CSR with signature over DER like we have done with C509 certificates. But having a type int is likely good anyway.
-  the rfc2986 name signaturealgorithm does not match the algorrithms in RFC 6955. I change the name PoP following 6955. Signature algorithms is now a special case.
- The RFC 6955 algorithm would need to get int code points in the draft..
-  rfc2986 does not sign the signature, but there seems to be no reason to not do this, so I made the format follow C509.
- I don't know which attributes would have to registered or if attributes are used.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Updated version

The section defines the C509 Certificate Signing Request (CSR) format based on and compatible with RFC 2986 {{RFC2986}} reusing the formatting for C509 certificates defined in {{certificate}}. There are currently two c509CertificateSigningRequestType values defined, c509CertificateSigningRequestType = 0 requests a c509CertificateType = 0 and c509CertificateSigningRequestType = 1 requests a c509CertificateType = 1 . subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm can be a C509 signature algorithm or a non-signature Proof-of-Possession Algorithm as defined in e.g. RFC 6955. CSR attributes other than extensionRequest are not supported.

```
C509CertificateSigningRequest = [
   TBSCertificateSigningRequest,
   subjectProofOfPossessionValue: any,
]

; The elements of the following group are to be used in a CBOR Sequence:
TBSCertificateSigningRequest = (
   c509CertificateSigningRequestType: int,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   extensionsRequest : Extensions,
   subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
)
```

After verifying the subjectProofOfPossessionValue, the CA MAY transform the C509CertificateSigningRequest into a RFC 2985 CertificationRequestInfo for compatibility with existing procedures and code.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I mentioned use case is that the CA decides which extentions to put in. The CSR format would then have to differentiate between asking for no extentions and to let the CA decide.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Unclear if any CSR attributes other than extensionsRequest need to be supported. Should the CSR format allow for future attributes or should that be left for a future 509CertificateSigningRequestType

comments.author: mcr
emanjon
comments.body:
Here is a list of varous alternatives:
----------------------------------------------

Subject creates

1) C509 CSR
2) PKCS#10 CSR
2) PKCS#10 CSR and compress it to C509 CSR


Issuer processes

a) C509 CSR 
b) PKCS#10
c) C509 CSR uncompressed to a PKCS#10 CSR
d) C509 CSR uncompressed to a PKCS#10 CertificationRequestInfo

Issuer delivers

α) C509 certificate of type 0
β) C509 certificate of type 1 (i.e X.509 compressed to C509)
γ) X.509

------------------------------------------------------------------

The current suggestion in the draft address the following four compbinations.

```
1) + a) + α)
1) + d) + α)

1) + a) + β)
1) + d) + β)
```

I did not think compression is as important for CSR as for the actual certificates. 
I think c) or d) is important to make it easy to add support in an existing CA.

Comments on what should be supported is very welcome.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
What is requested and the format of the request can also be expressed with headers / options "Accept" and "Content-Format", see 
https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore/issues/35

Maybe we should settle for just describing the format of the current CSR, i.e. c509CertificateRequestType with formats 1) and 3) above, analogous to c509CertificateType.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
Converging on allowing only the two following cases:

c509CertificateRequestType: 1 => use both compressed CSR and X509
c509CertificateRequestType: 0 => use both native cbor-CSR and C509

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
*update* / Carsten's proposal
c509CertificateRequestType: 3 => use both compressed CSR and X509
c509CertificateRequestType: 0 => use both native cbor-CSR and C509

issues.author: StefanHri

In section A.1.1 the public key is encoded as:
```
58 21 02 B1 21 6A B9 6E 5B 3B 33 40 F5 BD F0 2E 69 3F 16 21 3A 04 52 5E D4 44 50 B1 01 9C 2D FD 38 38 AB

The second byte (0x21) indicates the length of the byte string. The length is 32 byte which is in hex 0x20 not 0x21?

issues.title: CSR for Certificates containing static DH keys
issues.author: StefanHri
issues.body:
EDHOC has a static DH authentication mode. For that mode, we can use CBOR certificates containing the public DH key. According to RFC2986 the CSR contains a signature calculated with the own private key:

```
   The process by which a certification request is constructed involves
   the following steps:

        1. A CertificationRequestInfo value containing a subject
           distinguished name, a subject public key, and optionally a
           set of attributes is constructed by an entity requesting
           certification.

        2. The CertificationRequestInfo value is signed with the subject
           entity's private key.  (See Section 4.2.)

        3. The CertificationRequestInfo value, a signature algorithm
           identifier, and the entity's signature are collected together
           into a CertificationRequest value, defined below.
```
Since we cannot calculate a signature with the private DH key how should we construct a CSR which contains a static public DH key?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Proof of possession of static ECDH is defined in section 6 of RFC 6955. This reduces the size of the CSR since the signature is replaced with a MAC. It requires the requesting endpoint to have the static DH key of CA. (This can be acquired using GET /rpks, see draft-selander-ace-coap-est-oscore.)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: We believe it is solved through including the needed MAC algorithms in the issuer signature algorithms table

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
> We believe it is solved through including the needed MAC algorithms in the issuer signature algorithms table

... and a note about out of band establishment of public DH key of the verifier. All included in master now, last commit: d818f10.

issues.title: File format for saving CBOR certificates and CSRs
issues.author: StefanHri
issues.body:
What is the recommended file format for saving CBOR certificates and CSRs? 
Is it .der?

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Hi, I think that we should have a MIME TYPE for them. Within that, we would want to define an extension.  Maybe ".ccert"
or ".ccrt".

There is a tussle between having a 4-8-byte magic number at the beginning of the certificate, vs having a really short CBOR tag for transmission.  I suggest we not compromise, but do both.  I had this problem this week, and I want to propose that the 
file format for a .ccert is actually:

CBOR-Sequence [
   Tag<u64-magic-number>
   Encoded-Certificate...
]

Note that we have in the PEM vs DER certificate world, a problem: ".pem" files evolved to support having multiple certificates in them.  (and even having a private key and then series of certificates), but the DER encoded equivalents do not support that.
So, let's EXPLICITELY support CBOR-Sequence of certificates, and let's allow that the first item might be just a tag.

I will write a document for CBOR WG, on allocating this /etc/magic, file(1) friendly tag.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: We now have draft-ietf-cbor-file-magic, which makes a concrete BCP on this.

issues.title: Certificate chain optimizations
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
In self-issued certficates as well as when cbor certificates are used in chains/bags like the TLS certificate message or COSE c5chain, c5bag there is a lot of duplicated informatation. 

The issuer field is almost always the same as a subject field in the same or another certificate.
The authority key identifier key identifier is almost always the same as a subject key identifier in the same or another certificate.
The authority key identifier  authority Cert Issuer is almost always the same as subject field in the same or another certificate.

CBOR certificates could provide optimizations for self-issues certificates (they are send on the wire quite often in TLS, e.g. tools.ietf.org) as well as for certs that are sent in an certificate chain.

The issuer and key identifier in these cases could just be a relative pointer to the certificate with the information. I.e. typically 0 or 1.

For the example tools.ietf.org certificate the saving are quite large. 1075 bytes instead of 1242 bytes and for self-issued certs with a larger authority key information the saving are even bigger.

Should CBOR certificates provide optizations for self-issued certificates. I.e. issuer and auth key id is replaced with 0?
Should CBOR certificates provide optizations for certs in chains . I.e. issuer and auth key id is replaced with 1?

+ Provides large savings.
- Added coplexity, Makes CBOR compression two pass 
- May not be needed for TLS with Brotli as Brotli hopefully compresses these things anyway (should be tested)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Brotli support can be supported by new COSE header format(s)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Agreement to leave as is!

issues.title: Implications of CBOR cert being a CBOR sequence not a data item
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
A CBOR sequence can’t be an item in a CBOR array or the value of a CBOR map entry. The only way to use a CBOR sequence in a CBOR protocol is to wrap it in a byte string. That means whenever a CBOR Certificate is used in another CBOR protocol is must be wrapped in a byte string.

This is in contrast to many other CBOR protocols that are not CBOR sequences and thus don’t need the byte string wrapping when incorporated into another CBOR protocol. CBOR Cert seems unusual in its design choice.

The c5chain and c5bag COSE headers are the incorporation of CBOR Cert into the COSE protocol. The way they are defined now, there is byte string wrapping inherited from the x5bag and x5chain header parameters, so it does work.

It seems very easy and inexpensive to make CBOR Cert like the other protocols by just making it into a CBOR array. It would add one byte to the start of the cert.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I think wrapping in an array is the way to go. The COSE header parameters for C509 are now defined as doule arrays

COSE_C5 = [ [ + C509Certificate ] ]

Could be that the the inner [] should be included in C509Certificate, but this would add a byte for non-CBOR protocols like TLS. I don't the array help there. So maybe the current definition is the best.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
This is what is in the draft now, I'm I'm pretty sure it is incorrect CDDL:

`  COSE_C5 = [ + CBORCertificate ]`

The problem is that CBORCertificate is a group, not an array or a sequence-wrapping byte string. There's no structure to tell the end of one certificate from the start of the next in COSE_C5.

My preferred solution would be to make CBORCertificate an array instead of a sequence. It will add one byte for all uses of compressed certs, but it will reduce complexity a lot by making it like a more normal CBOR protocol. People will keep making mistakes like the one right now in COSE_C5 unless we make it an array. If we can't even get it right, think of what will happen for others.

So I prefer this fix:
```
CBORCertificate = [
   TBSCertificate,
   issuerSignatureValue : any,
]
```

With this the above COSE_C5 works correctly.

If CBORCertificate is left as a sequence because you really really want to save that one byte, then COSE_C5 can be fixed with arrays like this:
`  COSE_C5 = [ + [CBORCertificate]]`
or with byte-string wrapping like this:
`  COSE_C5 = [ + bstr .cborseq CBORCertificate ]`

If CBORCertificate is kept as a sequence, then one of the above two solutions will have to be used **every** time a CBORCertificate is put into another CBOR protocol. You only save the one byte in non-CBOR protocols like TLS!

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>This is what is in the draft now, I'm I'm pretty sure it is incorrect CDDL:
>
>COSE_C5 = [ + CBORCertificate ]

I don't know why you think this was incorrect CDDL.

RFC 8610 has the following example

[+(left: uint, right: uint)]

Also, this is not in the current version. It has already been changes in the GitHub version based on the discussions during the interim

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
Updated / fixed in current 04 draft, using the proposed array wrapping:
C509Certificate = [
       TBSCertificate,
       issuerSignatureValue : any,
 ]
- Closing

issues.title: Should a tag be defined?
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
It is common to define a tag for CBOR messages. For example COSE and CWT have tags. Should a tag be defined? 

I don't think you can tag a sequence, so it would have to be an array. See #83

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Make sense to define a tag for a CBOR certificate. 

https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bormann-cbor-notable-tags-02 defines

   *  Tag 63, registered by this document, is a parallel to tag 24, with
      the single difference that its byte string tag content carries a
      CBOR Sequence [RFC8742] instead of a single CBOR data items.

But if I understand correctly that is a sequence embedded in a bstr embedded in a tag.

Defining a tag-array-seq would make sense

Accorting to draft-ietf-cose-x509-08:

      The referenced resource can be any of the following media types:
      *  application/pkix-cert [RFC2585]
      *  application/pkcs7-mime; smime-type="certs-only" [RFC8551]

Accorting to draft-ietf-cose-x509-08:

      The URI provided MUST provide integrity protection and server
      authentication.  For example, an HTTP or CoAP GET request to
      retrieve a certificate MUST use TLS [RFC8446] or DTLS
      [I-D.ietf-tls-dtls13]. 

    For c5u we definitly want to allow OSCORE as well.

Is there any known software implementation for generating, validating and managing CBOR certificates, as well as converting X.509 certificates into the CBOR format?

My colleague Stefan (@StefanHri) and I work as research associates at Fraunhofer AISEC and are interested in implementing such functions in the form of a command-line tool and eventually as an expansion to our [uedhoc-uoscore](https://github.com/Fraunhofer-AISEC/uoscore-uedhoc) implementation, which is lead by Stefan.

issues.title: Comments from Ilari
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
I am trying to write an implementation of draft-mattsson-cose-cbor-cert-compress,
some comments on editor's draft about things that came up:


- Section 3.3. Encoding of Extensions says that:

  "Critical extensions are encoded with a positive sign and non-critical
  extensions are encoded with a negative sign."

  However, section 8.3. C509 Certificate Extensions Registry has:

  0 -> Subject Key Identifier

  0 is neither positive nor negative, so sign-flipping can not be
  used with it. 

  Name kinds do similar name flipping, but there at least is no
  name kind 0.

- Section 3.3. Encoding of Extensions says that:

  "Critical extensions are encoded with a positive sign and non-critical
  extensions are encoded with a negative sign."

  However, section 3.3.1. Example Encoding of Extensions contains a
  number of examples, where seemingly sign is used in exactly the
  opposite way (positive is non-critical, negative is critical).

- Section 8.3. C509 Certificate Extensions Registry has:

  Authority Key Identifier -> bytes

  However, section 3.3. Encoding of Extensions says:

  "authorityKeyIdentifier. extensionValue is encoded as an array where"

  So AKI may be an array.

- Section 3.3. Encoding of Extensions has CDDL, which has derivation:

  ExtValueAKI -> bytes

  However, the prose does not seem to say what having bytes there
  means.

  It would make sense to use bytes to mean AKI that has only the
  keyIdentifier field, as that is seemignly the most common case, and
  it would make AKI match up with SKI. 

- Section 8.3. C509 Certificate Extensions Registry has:

  Extended Key Usage -> int

  However, section 3.3. Encoding of Extensions says:

  "extKeyUsage. extensionValue is encoded as an array of"

  So EKU may be an array.

- Section 3.1. Message Fields says:

  "If the array contains exactly two ints and the absolute value of the
  first int is 2, the array is omitted and"

  Extension 2 is Subject Alternative Name, which does not admit int
  as argument (only array and text).

- Unknown algorithms with no parameters could be encoded as bytes
  instead of current [bytes].

- Unknown non-critical extensions could be encoded as (bytes, bytes)
  instead of current (bytes, false, bytes).

- This may be intentional, but looks bit odd: RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 with
  SHA-256 is 23, which is 1 byte int, whereas all the other RSA
  signatures use 2 byte identifiers.

issues.title: Describe CA processing
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The property that C509 can be deployed as a small shim layer at existing CAs should be given more space and be explained better. I that is one of the big motivations and advantages with C509. An existing CA can continue to use their existing procedures and code for PKCS#10 and DER encoded X.509 and only implement C509 as a layer on top of that.

When receiving a C509 CSR, the CA transforms it into a DER encoded RFC 2986 CertificationRequestInfo and use that with existing processes and code to produce an RFC 5280 DER encoded X509 certificate. The DER encoded X509 is then transformed into a C509 certificate.

comments.author: highlunder

issues.title: RPKI certificates as a use case
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
RPKI certificates are huge, partly due to inefficient encoding. C509 could really help making RPKI certificates smaller.

RPKI X.509 certificates are using the extensions defined in RFC 3779.

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3779

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Now supported! Closing as completed

issues.title: Compression of extentions, certificates, or chains.
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The TLS size examples in the -01 draft shows that even after C509 encoding, Brotli can still compress a cetificate chain quite much.

Test on RPKI certs should that Brotli can compress individual extensions or certs quite much, even after CBOR encoding.

I think we should discuss if Brotli (or some other general compression mechanism should be used in COSE. Likely after the signature has been calculated, i.e. not in individual extensions.

- C509 could specify a compressed cert type which take a C509 cert and produce a compressed C509.
- COSE_C509 could specify a compressed chain cert type which take a COSE_C509 cert and produce a compressed COSE_C509.

There has also been discussion on using CBOR packed, but there has to my knowledge not been any tests being done. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cbor-packed-02

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I think we should define COSE_C509 as something like 

COSE_C509 = [ comp : int, C509Certificate / [ 2* C509Certificate ] / bytes]

where comp = 0 is no compression and other values of comp are use for a compressed chain conveyed in a bstr. This provides significant further compression when applied to example HTTPS certificate chains. The numbers below are from TLS but would be approximate for COSE_C509 as well.
```

+-------------------+------+---------------+
|                   | C509 | C509 + Brotli |
+-------------------+------+---------------+
| ECDSA HTTPS Chain | 1409 |          1058 |
+-------------------+------+---------------+
| RSA HTTPS Chain   | 3957 |          2841 |
+-------------------+------+---------------+
```

CBOR packed could be used in a similar way (unclear how that performs)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Agreement to not address here as part of C509

issues.title: id-pe-tlsfeature and subject information access should likely be supported
issues.author: emanjon

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Solved through PR#131

issues.title: Further comments from Ilari
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/1z42o2SlausqLDoyr_WTUNf39HQ/


I have written a test CBOR X509 codec. From its issue notes, I found a
related issue note:

 "GeneralName can start with uint, so it is pretty nasty to determine
 if any uint in maximum position is in fact a maximum or start of
 next name. This probably will not work at all if GeneralName ever
 gains a type that can take uint as argument. And since minimum has
 a default, it is in fact optional, so the only required field is
 the GeneralName one."
 
However, the issue resolution note is busted (broken CDDL), and looking
at the code, the minimum/maximum handling is FUBAR.

In light of Corey's above mail, I just ripped out the minimum/maximum
handling, making those generate extension unencodeable if present.

Now each X.509 GeneralSubtree is encoded as CBOR GeneralName.




Some other notes I found:


 Certificate policies extension:

  The qualifier value field is of type dependent of qualifier id.
  Different qualfiers seem to put different things there. CPS seems
  to be IA5String, and unotice seems to be sequence{text}. If some cert
  has something else, who knows what the value is. The value field in
  CBOR is text, so sticking raw ASN.1 blobs is not possible.

  => Only qualifiers id-qt-cps and id-qt-unotice are supported.

* Key Usage extension:

  The present encoding seems to be ambiguous. For example, both 06 C0
  (committing signature certificate) and 01 06 (CA certificate) seem
  to encode as integer 3. With 1 prepended, those encode as integer 7
  and integer 131 respecively.

  => Prepend 1 bit to key usage before encoding.

* Name Constraints extension:

  Both permitted and excluded fields are optional, but the spec is not
  clear how missing field is encoded. The cbor-cert spec allows for
  empty array, while PKIX does not allow empty field. However, for
  implementations, it would be easier to encode absent field as
  null.

  => Encode missing permitted/excluded as null.

* Subject Directory Attributes extension:

  The ASN.1 is effectively list of tuples of OID and set.
  The CBOR is tuple of OID and set. There is no obvious way to map
  between the two. Furthermore, the present construction produces
  two values, which is not legal for extension, which can only
  produce one.

  => Use SubjectDirectoryAttributes = [+Attributes]

* Attribute table:

  Presently jurisdictionOfIncorporationCountryName and domainComponent
  both have id 21.
  
  => Encode domainComponent as 22.

* AS numbers extension:

  Is there a reason the numbers can not backjump?
  
  => Encode backjumps by overflowing 32-bit ASN.

* "AS Resources v2 (id-pe-ipAddrBlocks-v2)":

  I presume the OID should be id-pe-autonomousSysIds-v2.
  
* Section about "IP Resources" talks about "previous ASid".

  This looks odd...

* IPv6 address encoding can overflow:

  In encoding IPv6 addresses, the address differences can overflow
  uint. However, I do not expect this happening outside pathological
  cases, especially as CBOR ints go to full size of IPv6 subnetwork
  identifier.

* The encodings of Brainpool curves:

  The payload seems to be 20 octets, but the topmost TLV has length of
  19.

  => Fix topmost TLV length to 20 (0x14).

 * The encodings of ANSSI curve:

  The payload seems to be 21 octets, but the topmost TLV has length of
  19.

  => Fix topmost TLV length to 21 (0x15).

* Authority Key Identifier Extension:

  In pile of CA certs I have laying around, about 1/10 lack keyid in
  AKI.

  => Encode absent keyid as null.


Throwing the pile of CA certs I have at the implementation:

* 24 certificates have fatal errors that prevent compression:
  - 15 have bad notBefore
  - 3 have EKU explicitly not critical
  - 2 are X509v1 certificates
  - 2 have disagreeing signature algorithms
  - 1 has negative serial number
  - 1 has bad notAfter
* 15 certs hit error encoding CRL Distribution Point:
  ("Entry is not a pure DISTRIBUTION_POINT")
* 405 certs hit error encoding Certificate Policies:
  - 326 "Unsupported VisibleString notice"
  - 42 "Unsupported BMPString notice"
  - 29 "Unsupported notice reference"
  - 8 "FFCS VisibleString"
- 5 certs hit error encoding Authority Key Identifier:
  ("Invalid serial in AKI").
- 236 certs have Authority Key Identifier without keyid.

issues.title: Storing C509 certificates in DNS, using DANE: add new IANA consideration
issues.author: highlunder
issues.body:
DNS could be used to store C509 certificates, using DANE:

The DANE RR (TLSA) has four semantics for the "Certificate Usage Field", see section 2.1.1 of RFC6698, https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6698

To include C509 as an accepted format, a new selector value should be added, as an IANA consideration in the current draft.

See also "[COSE] Comments about draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert" from 2022-11-08

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
The comment from mcr was:

I think that Bob wants to store C509 certificates in DNS, using DANE.
The DANE RR (TLSA) has four semantics for the "Certificate Usage Field"
(see section 2.1.1 of RFC6698).

The stuff inside the RR is either an X.509 format certificate, or it may be a
SubjectPublicKeyInfo (RPK), or a SHA-256/512 of the above.

I think that Bob is asking if we should have a new Selector value for C509.
That would be IANA Considerations work that cose-cbor-encode-cert would do,
much like it does the TLS Certificates Types Registry.
(That field is Specification Required, so our document would be enough)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Status: Göran and John to bring up in discussions with Robert Moskowitz to clarify

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Is this just a matter of a value for C509 in the TLSA Selectors registry?

https://www.iana.org/assignments/dane-parameters/dane-parameters.xhtml#selectors

comments.author: bellebaum
comments.body:
@gselander Not quite. The quote from [RFC 6698, section 2.1.1](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6698#section-2.1.1):

> The certificate usages defined in this document explicitly only apply
   to PKIX-formatted certificates in DER encoding [[X.690](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6698#ref-X.690)].  If TLS
   allows other formats later, or if extensions to this RRtype are made
   that accept other formats for certificates, those certificates will
   need their own certificate usage values.

There are probably some interesting interactions between the formats, given that you can convert between them without changing the signature. This will require a sentence or two of clarifications on how to interpret the above quote, I guess. Maybe even referencing RFC 6698 as being updated by this draft to lessen the restriction?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Could we propose this draft to update the registry to allow C509?

issues.title: Is the reduction of certificate size the killer feature of C509?
issues.author: ralienpp
issues.body:
After reading rev-05 of the draft, my understanding is that _size reduction_ is the main benefit of switching to C509. This is outlined in the introduction, and to the best of my knowledge, no further advantages are mentioned, except maybe: "... removes the need for ASN.1 encoding, which is a rich source of security vulnerabilities".

I put on the devil's advocate hat, perhaps this will help shape the RFC in a way that builds a more convincing sales pitch.

1. Are there other immediate benefits besides a lower size?
2. I am not at all convinced by "ASN1 is a rich source of vulnerabilities". Unless CBOR is somehow intrinsically more secure by design, what makes us think that all CBOR parsers will be implemented without errors? While I admit that ASN.1 inflicted a lot of suffering unto me, I don't think it is judged fairly here.
3. How future-proof is the C509 in the light of post-quantum crypto, where keys and signatures are much larger? (see pic at the bottom) A random key should not contain patterns, so it wouldn't be compressible; if the key takes the lion's share of the cert's size, wouldn't the benefits of C509 become less tangible?

**Potential upsides**:
Is it possible to construct an argument that CBOR would require _fewer computing resources_ to handle? For example, if one could claim that deserializing CBOR takes less RAM or fewer CPU cycles, or a shallower call stack... then it would be a strong reason in favour of using it on constrained IoT devices.

In addition, could one claim that CBOR _lowers the cognitive burden_ on programmers? The built-in diagnostic representation is very useful, and one can easily convert it to JSON - so the existing skills would be easily transferable.



P.S. MITRE reports [137 ASN.1-related vulnerabilities](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvekey.cgi?keyword=asn.1), ~2200 for XML and 872 for JSON. CBOR has only 5 entries, but relatively speaking - it is the "new kid on the block", whereas ASN.1 has been around for almost 40 years and is very widely used.


Re: key sizes: here's an excerpt from Wikipedia's PQcrypto page:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/295338/216085304-d8980887-e2c6-44e1-9137-d8eb18fe14ba.png)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
First of all, a big thank you for your questions and observations! We should definitely first be able to motivate the work well enough to those that already have an interest in the area if we should be able to reach a wider audience.

There are additional other aspects to it, but my reasoning is the following;

I agree that the byte savings per individual certificate is not a strong enough motivation on its own. A wider perspective is that moving to a CBOR encoded format is in line with the other newer IoT standards, such as COSE and those that use it, for instance, EDHOC and OSCORE. For a ‘powerful enough’ IoT device it is probably ok to keep multiple libraries around to do similar tasks and hence be able to handle both CBOR and ASN.1. But being able to trim the library dependencies to a minimal usage profile is part of why I think moving to CBOR based encodings makes sense.

+There are ongoing discussions on how to incorporate the C509 format into both enrollment and revocation operations for IoT, which are currently more heavy-weight operations that are not easily trimmed down if one needs to keep full backward X.509 compatibility.  

In a sense, the above arguments are in line with your ‘lowers the cognitive burden on programmers’ observation. + The fewer libraries and dependencies, the lower the cost to do a more strict security analysis. 

About the ‘potentially fewer computing resources to process’; except for the special case of ECC public key compression; this will continue to be dependent on the signature algorithms used, handled by the crypto libs considered outside of the certificate format itself. As long as both X.509 and C509 are capable of specifying and carrying the ‘most efficient for IoT devices to validate’-signatures, I don’t see any difference in this area. 

About the need for longer keys, and especially longer signatures to be quantum safe(r); Yes, with larger key+signature data to handle, on one hand, the extra cert data is relatively smaller, but that shouldn’t mean we ignore it. To further complicate things, for the hash-based algorithms / at least one of the leading PQC candidate signature algorithms HSS/LMS, they “can only be used for a fixed number of signing operations”. (https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8778.html) →  We might end up needing to do more frequent certificate renewals. This can be seen as an argument either for or against caring about the relatively small additional cost of the other cert data. Having said this, while it’s definitely time to start planning for PQCs, I think we have some more years to efficiently handle the system and algorithms we use today. 

Once again, thank you for the observations! I hope we, through our continued work, will be able to make the potential advantages sufficiently clear.

+For the interested, some further PQC reading:

"An Update on NIST’s Post-Quantum Crypto Standardization":
https://x9.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PQC-update-2020.pdf

"LMS vs XMSS: Comparion of two Hash-Based Signature Standards"
https://eprint.iacr.org/2017/349.pdf

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: +We have discussions in the text on the efficiency of cbor, processing and small code size.

issues.title: encoding of Weierstrass EC public key in the native C509 certificate
issues.author: highlunder
issues.body:
It is not clear whether the EC Point (public key) is uncompressed encoded (starting with 0x04) or compressed (starting with 0x02 or 0x03) is used in the native C509 certificate.

If uncompressed encoded, then the following text needs to be adapted:

'For elliptic curve public keys in Weierstrass form (id-ecPublicKey), *uncompressed keys are point compressed* as defined in Section 2.3.3 of [[SECG](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-05.html#SECG)]'.

A suggestion is
'For elliptic curve public keys in Weierstrass form (id-ecPublicKey), *public keys are uncompressed encoded EC points* as defined in Section 2.3.3 of [[SECG](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-05.html#SECG)]'.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Clarified in text as always point compressed

comments.author: xipki
comments.body:
I my view, the only advantage of compressed point encoding is:
1. Reduce size (e.g., 32 bytes compared to uncompressed)

This, however, is problematic, since it is not so widely supported as the uncompressed version, e.g. unsupported in mbedTLS (https://github.com/Mbed-TLS/mbedtls/issues/861).

Please also note the compressed point is deprecated in TLS 1.2 and 1.3 (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-tls-rfc4492bis-16#section-5.1.2).

issues.title: To simplify the process of C509 native CRLs
issues.author: highlunder
issues.body:
To simplify the process of C509 native CRLs, what about extracting some extensions from the 'extensions' field and assigning explicit fields for such extensions?

1. CRL extensions 'CRL number' and 'AuthorityKeyIdentifier':

TBSCertificateSigningRequest = (
   C509CertificateRevocationListType: int,
   issuer: Name,
   thisUpdate: Time,
   nextUpdate: Time,
   **crlNumber: ~biguint,** ;new field
   **AuthorityKeyIdentifier: ~bstr,**; new field
   revokedCertificates: RevokedCertificates,
   crlExtensions: Extensions, ; all extensions except CRLNumber and AuthorityKeyIdentifier
   issuerSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
)

2. CRL entry extension 'crlReason':

RevokedCertificates = [
    userCertificate: CertificateSerialNumber,
    revocationDate: Time,
    **crlReason: ~uint,**; new field
    crlEntryExtensions: Extensions, ; all extensions except crlReason.
]

-- Lijun Liao, https:[github.com/xipki](http://github.com/xipki)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: We authors argue that we need to keep the existing encoding, at least if we want to support the compression of existing requests, which is desired.

issues.title: Why not uncompressed-encode the Weierstrass EC public key in the native C509 certificate?
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
I my view, the only advantage of compressed point encoding is the reduce size (e.g., 32 bytes compared to uncompressed for P-256 curve).

This, however, is problematic, since it is not so widely supported as the uncompressed version, e.g. unsupported in mbedTLS (https://github.com/Mbed-TLS/mbedtls/issues/861).

Please also note the compressed point is deprecated in TLS 1.2 and 1.3 (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-tls-rfc4492bis-16#section-5.1.2).

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: We believe that point compression will be relevant in the future, even if the current support is less than desired. To address this, we are currently discussing how we could also support uncompressed versions of the keys.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I made a PR supporting uncompressed. #117

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
My reading of RFC 8422 and RFC 8446 are that they are for the ECDHE key shares. TLS typically does not specify anything about X.509 as that is out of scope of TLS.

Calculating the uncompressed y coordinate is not very hard as explained in Section 3.2 of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-mattsson-tls-compact-ecc-04

`we can calculate y as the square root w = (x^3 + a ⋅ x + b)^((p + 1)/4) (mod p)`

This is very simple math, nothing ECC specific and the implementation does not need any specific security considerations as it operates on public data. But maybe it is problematic to implement on more contrained devices.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: With the latest update from John, both compressed and uncompressed encodings of Weierstrass EC public keys are supported. We think this is the best way forward.

issues.title: Code point for the Bundle Protocol Endpoint ID
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/lIFCHDgM0gqSfJEnnI7qfOxzhqc/


Assign initial code point in the “C509 General Names Registry” for the Bundle Protocol Endpoint ID. 

>>This otherName form was allocated in RFC 9174 [2] and has an existing compressed CBOR form defined in RFC 9171 [3] (with a CDDL symbol “eid-structure” defined in that document). I don’t think there would be much more work than referencing those existing otherName OID and the CDDL symbol (or simply copy-pasting that symbol definition), or  I could propose specific text to fit in Figure 13 if desired.>>
 
 
[1] https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-06.html#section-11.8

issues.title: Typo in EKU registry table
issues.author: BrianSipos
issues.body:
It appears that there is a typo in code point 13 entry of [Figure 12](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-06.html#figure-12) that the OID and Comments are correct, but the Name and Identifiers are incorrect copy-paste from code point 11 (the KDC object).

It seems like the Identifiers should probably be the `id-kp-secureShellServer` of the [IANA Table](https://www.iana.org/assignments/smi-numbers/smi-numbers.xhtml#smi-numbers-1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3) and the Name something like "SSH Server".

issues.title: Add support for challengePassword attribute
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
Section 4 states that

> CSR attributes other than extensionRequest are not supported.

but the challengePassword attribute is used in [RFC 9148](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9148) and [est-oscore](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ace-coap-est-oscore/) and should also be supported.

In PKCS#9 ([RFC 2985](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2985)) and PKCS#10 ([RFC 2986](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2986)), challengePassword is encoded as a text string and the example given is for revocation, which probably is not relevant. 

In SCEP ([RFC 8994](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc8994)), challengePassword is intended to be a shared secret, and it is RECOMMENDED to be a one-time authenticator.

In the later references mentioned above challengePassword is used for associating the certificate request to the authenticated session and the assumed encoding is byte string.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Should we add general attributes, or just challengePassword as an additional field?

OLD
TBSCertificateRequest = (
   c509CertificateRequestType: int,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   extensionsRequest : Extensions,
   subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
)


NEW
TBSCertificateRequest = (
   c509CertificateRequestType: int,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   _**challengePassword: bstr / null,**_
   extensionsRequest : Extensions,
   subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
)

(or is it _**nil**_?)

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: We propose to add the challenge password as an Extension, part of the extensionsRequest field. This would save the otherwise additional null-byte needed to always have the option present at the top level.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Pushed!

comments.author: xipki
comments.body:
> Should we add general attributes, or just challengePassword as an additional field?
> 
> OLD TBSCertificateRequest = ( c509CertificateRequestType: int, subject: Name, subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier, subjectPublicKey: any, extensionsRequest : Extensions, subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier, )
> 
> NEW TBSCertificateRequest = ( c509CertificateRequestType: int, subject: Name, subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier, subjectPublicKey: any, _**challengePassword: bstr / null,**_ extensionsRequest : Extensions, subjectProofOfPossessionAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier, )
> 
> (or is it _**nil**_?)

Just for clarity, adding new field `challengePassword:bstr/null`does not work here for re-encoded X.509 CSR. Since the position relationship between the attribute `challengePassword`and the attribute `extensionsRequest`is lost.

issues.title: Encoding of timestamp
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
> the timestamp is encoded as a CBOR int (milliseconds since validityNotBefore)

Is CBOR int correct? validityNotBefore is encoded as Time.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
Since the timestamp tag is defined as millisec in rfc6962, we keep it as millisec encoded as long/int for practical purposes.

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6962

issues.title: Byte string encoding of text string assumes even number of symbols
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
Section 3.1

issuer / subject

> If the text string contains only the symbols '0'-'9' or 'a'-'f', it is encoded as a CBOR byte string, prefixed with an initial byte set to '00'.

The byte string encoding assumes an even number of symbols.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Fixed in master

issues.title: Missing media types and content formats
issues.author: gselander
issues.body: https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore/issues/34 requests definition of media types, including that of CBOR encoded CSR.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: +We should support cbor encoding of private keys, and define corresponding media types (see PKCS#8 for origin)

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: As an equivalent of the PKCS #8 encoding of a private key, isn't that just equivalent to a COSE-key structure which is already defined for COSE?  I'm hoping we can re-use where we can.  application/cose-key is already registered.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I added a media type for C509CertificateRequest.

I think @EskoDijk has a point that we should be able to use the media type application/cose-key for a COSE key instead of defining a new for transporting some encoding of PKCS#8 (which?).

Have we then resolved https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore/issues/34 ?

comments.author: malishav
comments.body: Another thing that is missing is the registration of CoAP Content-Format identifiers for the newly registered Media Types.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>Another thing that is missing is the registration of CoAP Content-Format identifiers for the newly registered Media Types.

Would we need several content formats indicating chain and bag? Or is just chain or just bag enough?

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
From what I see in the registration text there's two possible CoAP content-format IDs:

* application/cose-c509
* application/cose-c509;usage=chain

Now both media types could contain either one C509Certificate, or a CBOR array of two or more C509Certificate.  (Arguably a chain of 1 is not so useful, but it's allowed, right?)

This would mean you get 2 CoAP content-formats. The single cert case and the bag case are captured by the first.

One question this brings up: if a receiver receives media type "application/cose-c509" data, and the top level structure is a CBOR array of length 2, how would it easily detect whether this is
1) a single C509Certificate, or 
2) a bag with two C509Certificates in it?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>Arguably a chain of 1 is not so useful, but it's allowed, right?)
Yes

>One question this brings up: if a receiver receives media type "application/cose-c509" data, and >the top level structure is a CBOR array of length 2, how would it easily detect whether this is
>
>    a single C509Certificate, or
>    a bag with two C509Certificates in it?

You would need to look at the content. A single C509Certificate would be an array of length 11 while a bag with two C509Certificates would have length 2. To differentiate between a single C509Certificate and a bag with 11 C509Certificates you would need to look at the first element and see if it is an int or an array.

Would you need to determine that there is a single C509Certificate from the media type/content format alone without looking? We could potentially change both the media format or the encoding if needed.

`COSE_C509 = C509Certificate / [ 2* C509Certificate ]
`

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
Thanks @emanjon ; I see I made a mistake here in the example (not knowing the CDDL syntax exactly ... ) 

So the example could be a single cert (array of length 11) vs a bag of certs with 11 certs in it (array of length 11). It's unclear based on length alone, but looking at the first element would resolve it (either an int - or an array of length 11 - or something else, which then renders the data invalid).

> Would you need to determine that there is a single C509Certificate from the media type/content format alone without looking?

Not sure.  For X509 certs this distinction is made, e.g. single cert in type application/pkix-cert and a bag of certs in application/pkcs7-mime. But I don't see problems in doing it in one for C509.  (Perhaps some IETFers may not like doing this trial-and-error type of content processing to detect which flavor we're dealing with.)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>application/pkix-cert and a bag of certs in application/pkcs7-mime

Yes, the question is if this is just for historical reasons or if it is useful...

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
With content formats likely to be specified that will also be part of the file format #81.

From RFC 9277:
  

>    For CBOR data items that form a
>    representation that is already described by such a Content-Format
>    Number, a tag number has proactively been allocated in Section 4.3
>    (see Appendix B for details and examples).

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Fixed!

issues.title: Should NotAfter be made optional?
issues.author: highlunder
issues.body:
From Mike Ounsworth on the [COSE] draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-lists:

"The fact that notAfter is a mandatory field in X.509 is a major headache in some cases. RFC 5280 defines the special value 

   To indicate that a certificate has no well-defined expiration date,
   the notAfter SHOULD be assigned the GeneralizedTime value of
   99991231235959Z.

But in practice, this is not widely supported or even well-known enough to be universally usable.

Idea: could notAfter be made optional in C509? When transcoding to X.509 I suppose you would have to replace an absent notAfter with the GeneralizedTime value of 99991231235959Z.

The same could maybe be considered for notBefore."

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
"If that seems to far a step, let’s just use
        false
for
        99991231235959Z
Grüße, Carsten"

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Already included, using null!

issues.title: IPR and commercial use
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
Are there any IPR claims applied to the C509 certificates? In other words, is there any limitation to use C509 certificates in the commercial products?

Thanks!

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: There are no IPR disclosures made on C509 certificates in the IETF, and the authors of the draft are not aware of any IPR. The purpose of making this an IETF standard is to enable interoperable use in products. (Do let us know if you are interested in making interop. tests!)

comments.author: xipki
comments.body:
Hey Göran, thank you for the detailed answer.

I am the owner of an opensource PKI project (https://github.com/xipki/xipki). In the future, I will add the support of C509 (and as part of the interop. test). Specifications I am missing before I start the implementation are  at least:
- CBOR-encoded certificate management protocols, e.g. CBOR-encoded CMP/EST/ACME,
- CBOR-encoded CRL,
- CBOR-encoded OCSP, 
- C509 in TLS.

Can you share the roadmap to write these RFC standards?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Hi Lijun (@xipki), thanks for sharing, looks great!

Here are starting points for specs: 

* CBOR-encoded certificate management protocols, e.g. CBOR-encoded CMP/EST/ACME

I'm aware of two tracks here. One track is based on optimizations of EST with two instances: EST-CoAPs (RFC 9148) and EST-OSCORE (draft-ietf-ace-coap-est-oscore). Both these drafts are keeping much of the original REST APIs from EST (although abbreviated)  but it uses protocols more suitable for constrained environments, such as CoAP and DTLS, or CoAP and OSCORE (RFC 8613). OSCORE is built on CBOR and COSE: in short it is wrapping CoAP messages in COSE_Encrypt0. This is the closest you get to a CBOR encoded security protocol: Using EST-OSCORE with EDHOC (draft-ietf-lake-edhoc) then both the security handshake as well as the certificate enrollment is encoded in CBOR and COSE.
 
Another track is to do CMP over CoAP (RFC 9482). In this case the CMP PKIMessages are DER encoded.

* CBOR-encoded CRL
* CBOR-encoded OCSP

The revocation related text were taken out of draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert and put into a separate draft draft-cose-cbor-revocation-management is kept in a separate draft in the same github waiting to be submitted:
https://github.com/cose-wg/CBOR-certificates
As you can see, the CRL part is essentially done. There is an ongoing discussion about which optimizations to make on OCSP.

* C509 in TLS

draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert defines the certificate format in 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-07#name-tls-certificate-types-regis
Is there anything else you are missing?

Roadmaps are much to ask for. IETF works by building consensus among engaged people who are specifying and implementing things. If people are active and pro then things progress more quickly. We have been having this on the back burner for some time, now trying to wrap up the basic specification. More people are invited to contribute to the work, e.g. the revocation draft, which would speed up the process.

Formally work in the IETF is done in working groups. CBOR-encoded CRL/OSCP are both in scope of the COSE working group. Lightweight certificate enrollment protocols such as EST-CoAPs (RFC 9148) and EST-OSCORE are in scope of the ACE working group. All work progress is cleared through the mailing lists of the working groups, which are open and available to anyone. Welcome to join the work!

https://www.ietf.org/mailman/listinfo/COSE
https://www.ietf.org/mailman/listinfo/ACE

comments.author: xipki
comments.body:
Hi Göran,

- EST-CoAPs seems still to enroll the X.509 certificates.
- EST-SCORE (draft) looks good, it should be extended with more details. I can support here both in the specification text and implementation. Some customized extension in my opensource can also be added to this draft.
- CRL: This is the most complicated part compared to certificate and OCSP. There are (full CRL, delta CRL) x (direct CRL, indirect CRL). And in some cases the CRL could be very large (e.g. Apple's WWDR CRL, at least in 2020, contained over 1 million revoked certificates). We need to re-design the CRL, 1:1 mapping from X.509 is not a good idea.
- OCSP: I will check it once published.
- C509 in TLS: Yes. Do you plan to have this implemented in any popular TLS libraries, e.g. mbedtls?

BR/Lijun

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Hi Lijun,

Sorry for slow response. There are several topics here, some answers:

* EST-OSCORE: It would be interesting to hear more, please provide input to https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore
or if you prefer we can have a discussion first.
* Revocation: Yes, CRL is included partly because it is straightforward to define it given the encoding of certificates, clearly constrained environments may not be able to support that. OCSP is based on a previous master thesis but additional design choices are needed.

As for implementation, the first goal is to have implementations of the basic conversion X.509 <-- --> C509, other code is for later.
 
BR,
Göran

issues.author: highlunder

It seems Subject Information Access with OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.1.11 has been duplicated in C509 Extensions Registry, as 31 and 42.

Proposal is to just remove 42

comments.body: Seems like this should just be done....
