issues.title: Extend "Figure 9: C509 Certificate Policies" to support Certificate Policy Identifiers defined in EN 319 411-2.
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
Please consider whether to add registries for the Certificate Policy Identifiers defined in ETSI EN 319 411-2 and ETSI TS 119 495:

- ETSI EN 319 411-2

  - a) QCP-n: certificate policy for EU qualified certificates issued to natural persons;
    ```
     itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) qualified-certificate-policies(194112)
     policy-identifiers(1) qcp-natural (0)
    ```

  - b) QCP-l: certificate policy for EU qualified certificates issued to legal persons;
    ```
    itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) qualified-certificate-policies(194112).
    policy-identifiers(1) qcp-legal (1)
    ```

  - c) QCP-n-qscd: certificate policy for EU qualified certificates issued to natural persons with private key related
to the certified public key in a QSCD;
    ```
    itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) qualified-certificate-policies(194112)
    policy-identifiers(1) qcp-natural-qscd (2)
    ```

  - d) QCP-l-qscd: certificate policy for EU qualified certificates issued to legal persons with private key related to
the certified public key in a QSCD;
    ```
    itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) qualified-certificate-policies(194112)
    policy-identifiers(1) qcp-legal-qscd (3)
    ```

  - e) QCP-w: certificate policy for EU qualified website authentication certificates;
    ```
    itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) qualified-certificate-policies(194112)
    policy-identifiers(1) qcp-web (4)
    ```

- ETSI TS 119 495
  - QCP-w-psd2: certificate policy for EU PSD2 qualified website authentication certificates;
   ```
   qcp-web-psd2 OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::=
   { itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) psd2(19495) policy-identifiers(3) 1}
   ```

- Reference:
  - ETSI EN 319 411-2, Electronic Signatures and Infrastructures (ESI); Policy and security requirements for Trust Service Providers issuing certificates; Part 2: Requirements for trust service providers issuing EU qualified certificates. Available under  https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_en/319400_319499/31941102/02.03.01_60/en_31941102v020301p.pdf
  - ETSI TS 119 495, Electronic Signatures and Infrastructures (ESI); Sector Specific Requirements; Certificate Profiles and TSP Policy Requirements for Open Banking. Availabler under https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_ts/119400_119499/119495/01.06.01_60/ts_119495v010601p.pdf

issues.title: Syntax for the extnesion value QCStatements
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
The ASN.1 syntax:

- RFC 3739
  ```
  QCStatements ::= SEQUENCE OF QCStatement

   QCStatement ::= SEQUENCE {
       statementId        OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
       statementInfo      ANY DEFINED BY statementId OPTIONAL}

   SemanticsInformation  ::= SEQUENCE {
       semanticsIndentifier        OBJECT IDENTIFIER OPTIONAL,
       nameRegistrationAuthorities NameRegistrationAuthorities OPTIONAL
       } -- At least one field shall be present
 
   NameRegistrationAuthorities ::= SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF GeneralName

   id-qcs-pkixQCSyntax-v1   OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-qcs 1 } -- 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.11.1
   id-qcs-pkixQCSyntax-v2   OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-qcs 2 } -- 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.11.2
   ```

- ETSI EN 319 412-5
  ```
  -- EU qualified certificate declaration
  esi4-qcStatement-1 QC-STATEMENT ::= { IDENTIFIED BY id-etsi-qcs-QcCompliance }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcCompliance OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 1 }

  -- Declaration of limit value
  esi4-qcStatement-2 QC-STATEMENT ::= { SYNTAX QcEuLimitValue IDENTIFIED
     BY id-etsi-qcs-QcLimitValue }

  QcEuLimitValue ::= MonetaryValue

  MonetaryValue::= SEQUENCE {
      currency Iso4217CurrencyCode,
      amount INTEGER,
      exponent INTEGER}
      -- value = amount * 10^exponent

  Iso4217CurrencyCode ::= CHOICE {
     alphabetic PrintableString (SIZE (3)), -- Recommended
     numeric INTEGER (1..999) }
     -- Alphabetic or numeric currency code as defined in ISO 4217
     -- It is recommended that the Alphabetic form is used

  -- Retention period declaration
  esi4-qcStatement-3 QC-STATEMENT ::= { SYNTAX QcEuRetentionPeriod IDENTIFIED
      BY id-etsi-qcs-QcRetentionPeriod }

  QcEuRetentionPeriod ::= INTEGER 

  -- SSCD and QSCD declaration
  esi4-qcStatement-4 QC-STATEMENT ::= { IDENTIFIED BY id-etsi-qcs-QcSSCD }

  -- PKI Disclosure statements
  esi4-qcStatement-5 QC-STATEMENT ::= { SYNTAX QcEuPDS IDENTIFIED
      BY id-etsi-qcs-QcPDS }

  QcEuPDS ::= PdsLocations

  PdsLocations ::= SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF PdsLocation
  PdsLocation::= SEQUENCE {
      url IA5String,
     language PrintableString (SIZE(2))} --ISO 639-1 language code

  -- Certificate type
  esi4-qcStatement-6 QC-STATEMENT ::= { SYNTAX QcType IDENTIFIED
      BY id-etsi-qcs-QcType }

  QcType::= SEQUENCE OF OBJECT IDENTIFIER (id-etsi-qct-esign | id-etsi-qct-eseal |
      id-etsi-qct-web, ...)

  -- country or set of countries under the legislation of which the certificate is issued as a
  -- qualified certificate
  esi4-qcStatement-7 QC-STATEMENT ::= { SYNTAX QcCClegislation IDENTIFIED
      BY id-etsi-qcs-QcCClegislation } 

  QcCClegislation ::= SEQUENCE OF CountryName
  CountryName ::= PrintableString (SIZE (2)) (CONSTRAINED BY { -- ISO 3166 alpha-2 codes only -- })

  -- object identifiers
  id-etsi-qcs OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0)
      id-qc-profile(1862) 1 }
  id-etsi-qcs-QcCompliance OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 1 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcLimitValue OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 2 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcRetentionPeriod OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 3 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcSSCD OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 4 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcPDS OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 5 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcType OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 6 }

  id-etsi-qcs-QcCClegislation OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-etsi-qcs 7 }
  ```

- ETSI TS 119 495
  ```
  etsi-psd2-qcStatement QC-STATEMENT ::= {SYNTAX PSD2QcType IDENTIFIED BY id-etsi-psd2-qcStatement }

  id-etsi-psd2-qcStatement OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::=
      { itu-t(0) identified-organization(4) etsi(0) psd2(19495) qcstatement(2) }

  PSD2QcType ::= SEQUENCE{
      rolesOfPSP RolesOfPSP,
      nCAName NCAName,
      nCAId NCAId }

  NCAName ::= UTF8String (SIZE (1..256))

  NCAId ::= UTF8String (SIZE (1..256))

  RolesOfPSP ::= SEQUENCE OF RoleOfPSP

  RoleOfPSP ::= SEQUENCE{
      roleOfPspOid RoleOfPspOid,
      roleOfPspName RoleOfPspName}

  RoleOfPspOid ::= OBJECT IDENTIFIER 
  ```

- CBOR: below is my proposed suggestion:

  We need a new "Figure X: C509 Statement Identifiers", and the following syntax:

  ```
  QCStatements = [* QCStatement ]

  QCStatement = (statementId: int, statementInfo : any) /
                (statementId: ~oid/pen, statementInfo : bstr/null) -- statementInfo may be not present.

  -- For qcs-pkixQCSyntax-v1  and qcs-pkixQCSyntax-v2
  SemanticsInformation = [semanticsIdentifier:~oid/pen/null, nameRegistrationAuthorities:GeneralNames/null]

  -- For esi4-qcStatement-1
  The statementInfo is `null`.

  -- For  esi4-qcStatement-2
  MonetaryValue = [currency: Iso4217CurrencyCode, amount: uint, exponent: uint]

  Iso4217CurrencyCode = tstr / uint

  -- For  esi4-qcStatement-3
  The statementInfo is uint (or int if negative value is allowed).

  -- For esi4-qcStatement-4
  The statementInfo is `null`.

  -- For  esi4-qcStatement-5
  PdsLocations = [ + PdsLocation ]

  PdsLocation = (url:tstr, language:tstr)

  -- For  esi4-qcStatement-6
  QcType = [ * ~oid/pen ]

  -- For  esi4-qcStatement-7
  QcCClegislation = [*tstr]

  -- For etsi-psd2-qcStatement
  RoleOfPSP = (~oid/pen, tstr)

  RolesOfPSP = [* RoleOfPSP]

  PSD2QcType = [RolesOfPSP, tstr, tstr]
  ```

issues.title: Support FIPS 203, 204, and 205
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
NIST is working on the standardization of the PQC mechanisms:
- FIPS 203, [Module-Lattice-Based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism Standard](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/203/ipd)
- FIPS 204, [Module-Lattice-Based Digital Signature Standard](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/204/ipd)
- FIPS 205, [Stateless Hash-Based Digital Signature Standard](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/205/ipd)

These Standards are still in the draft version, and only minor changes are expected.
What do you think about to assign `int` numbers to the public key algorithms and signature algorithms?

Below are the public key algorithms and signature algorithms:
- FIPS 203:
  - Public Key Algorithms:
    - ML-KEM-512
    - ML-KEM-768
    - ML-KEM-1024 
  - Signature Algorithms: N/A
- FIPS 204
  - Here the IETF Draft specifies the key and signature syntax in PKIX: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lamps-x509-shbs-00 
  - Public Key Algorithms/Signature Algorithms:
    - ML-DSA-44
    - ML-DSA-65
    - ML-DSA-87
- FIPS 204
  - Public Key Algorithms/Signature Algorithms:
    - SLH-DSA-SHA2-128s
    - SLH-DSA-SHAKE-128s 
    - SLH-DSA-SHA2-128f
    - SLH-DSA-SHAKE-128f 
    - SLH-DSA-SHA2-192s
    - SLH-DSA-SHAKE-192s

    - SLH-DSA-SHA2-256s

issues.title: Simplify the CDDL of Name
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
In draft -09, name allows `RelativeDistinguishedName`with more than one `Attribute`. In the practice, it is rare to have such cases. If we exclude such cases, the CDDL of `Name` can be simplified:

From
```
    Name = [ * RelativeDistinguishedName ] / text / bytes

    RelativeDistinguishedName = Attribute / [ 2* Attribute ]
``` 
to
```
    Name = [ * Attribute ] / text / bytes
``` 

 This simplifies also the implmentation, especially in the native C509. As defined in current CDDL, we need
`Attribute[][]` to present a Name, while in the simplified CDDL, only Attribute`[]` is enough.

      ASIdentifiers = [ + AsIdsOrRanges ] / null

- Extension `id-pe-ipAddrBlocks`

issues.title: Deterministic Encoding of an Extension
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
To encode an extension of an X.509 certificate deterministically, I suggestion to follow one of the following methods to produce a distinct encoded C.509 certificate (of type 3).
- Method 1
  1. If the extensionID has an `int` assignment,
     1. If the extentionValue can be encoded as the syntax specified in "Figure 8: C509 Extensions and CSR Attributes", then the extension is encoded as (extensionID:int, extensionValue:any),
     2. otherwise if the syntax specified in "Figure 8" does not contain `bstr` choice, then the extension is encoded as (extensionID:int, extensionValue:bstr) where extensionValue is the DER-encoded extension value. (This applies to all extensions except `subjectKeyIdentifier` and `authorityKeyIdentifier`).
     3. otherwise the extension is encoded as (extensionID:~oid/pen, extensionValue:bstr) where extensionValue is the DER-encoded extension value. (This applies to the extensions `subjectKeyIdentifier` and `authorityKeyIdentifier`).
  2. otherweise the extension is encoded as in case i.c

- Method 2
  The same as Method 1, except there are no case i.b.

Method 1 needs less storage capability, but Method 2 is simpler to implement.

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body: Based on joint discussions, we are leaning towards Metod 2, but we will reach out and ask the COSE list for comments!

comments.author: highlunder
comments.body:
Have mailed the COSE list with the following content:

Regarding the ongoing work with draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert, we hope to get your opinions on some alternatives regarding non-determinism and compactness.
Our overall stance is that non-determinism in the c509 encoding cannot be fully avoided, if we at all want the draft to evolve and cover more relevant use cases in the future. But we need to both clarify and, as far as possible, reduce the cases where non-determinism could happen. A main area to clarify is the handling of certificate extensions:

*Previously we have allowed the registration of certificate extensions in our c509 extension table(^1), without requiring a full accomplishing specification of the cbor encoding of the extension value. Instead allowing the value to be a cbor byte string wrapping of the der-encoded value. This is a clear source of non-determinism, as the expectation is that later additions to the draft will further specify a cbor encoding of the value. The result would be that the receiver of a certificate cannot know beforehand if an extension value is cbor fully encoded or just a der endoced value with byte string wrapping.

*We think it would be a useful restriction to only keep extensions with defined cbor encodings of the value, and add this as a requirement for new entries into the table of supported extensions. 
*For encoded X.509 certificates, any extension would still supported through the more lengthy wrapping of the oid and bstr-wrapped extension value.
*We are leaning towards proposing that native c509 must only use cbor encoded extensions. This means that an X.509 extension, which is not covered in the C509 Extensions registry, must be added before being allowed in a native C509 certificate. 

Does this seem like reasonable restrictions and limitations? Comments and opinions here or directly to our github issue tracker(^2) are most welcome.

In addition, there has been an ongoing discussion on adding options for using PENs instead of OID. Since the the cbor encoding of the PENs would need a tag, the savings compared with unwrapped OIDs are only two bytes per PEN. At the same time, support for PEN adds complexity both in the specification and in implementations. To not increase the non-determinism, any OID which can be PEN encoded must be PEN encoded, requiring strict checking. This makes us question whether the savings are worth the drawbacks, and we are interested in hearing any supporting voices from either side of the issue.

1) Ref, C509 Extensions registry: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cose-cbor-encoded-cert-09#name-c509-extensions-registry

2) The main github issue regarding the non-determinism issue https://github.com/cose-wg/CBOR-certificates/issues/197

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Having not received any comments, we make the same change for extension as for attributes #198.

Pending input from John, we are in favor of requiring CBOR encoded extensions for native C509 certificates.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Summarizing my current understanding: 

Where there is support for (extensionID:int, extensionValue:any) of an extension, as specified in Section 3.3 it MUST be used. Otherwise the extension is encoded as (extensionID:~oid, extensionValue:bstr) where extensionValue is the DER-encoded extension value. Native C509 certificates MUST only use CBOR encoded extensions, and this aspect of the encoding becomes deterministic.

Indeterminism of non-native C509 certificates is a consequence of the extensibility of the C509 Extensions Registry. When decoding a non-native C509 certificates, the decoder needs to support an (extensionID:~oid, extensionValue:bstr)-encoding of an extension for which there is an (extensionID:int, extensionValue:any)-encoding , for example because the certificate was issued before the extension was registered.

issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
In draft -09, an Attribute is encoded as follows
```
    Attribute = ( attributeType: int, attributeValue: text ) //
                ( attributeType: ~oid/pen, attributeValue: bytes )
```

1. It is not clear how to encode the attribute, if it has the assigned `int` type, and
   - For emailAddress and domainComponent: the attribute value is not `IA5String` encoded,
   - For other attributes, the value is neither `PRINTABLE STRING` nor `UTF8 STRING` encoded.
2. Shall the attribte type be negative (for `PRINTABLE STRING`) or posive (for `UTF8 STRING`), if the attribute type is of fixed string type, but not one of `PRINTABLE STRING` and `UTF8 STRING`, e.g. the emailAddress and domainComponent?

issues.title: Public Key Value of XMSS, XMSSMT, and HSS-LMS
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
As specified in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lamps-x509-shbs-00:

```
pk-XMSS-HashSig PUBLIC-KEY ::= {
   IDENTIFIER id-alg-xmss-hashsig
   KEY XMSS-HashSig-PublicKey
   PARAMS ARE absent
   CERT-KEY-USAGE
      { digitalSignature, nonRepudiation, keyCertSign, cRLSign } }

XMSS-HashSig-PublicKey ::= OCTET STRING
```

And here the definition of SubjectPublicKeyInfo in RFC 5280
```
   SubjectPublicKeyInfo  ::=  SEQUENCE  {
        algorithm            AlgorithmIdentifier,
        subjectPublicKey     BIT STRING  }
```

Shall the XMSS public key be an OCTET-STRING(public key bytes), or just the "public key bytes"?

This applies also to the XMSS-MT, HSS-LMS.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: draft-ietf-lamps-x509-shbs-00 is an early draft still, leave this open until it has matured.

issues.title: Support the extensions in CCC Digital Key Specification
issues.author: xipki
issues.body:
CCC defines in its [Digital Key Specification ](https://carconnectivity.org/digital-key/) 10 extensions, most of them have simple extension value:

```
ExternalCACertificateExtensionSchema ::= SEQUENCE
{
  extension_version INTEGER (1..255)
}
```

Below is the complete list of extension OIDs:

B.2.2 OID Assignment

Each certificate shall be identifiable by the following OID values:

- Vehicle Public Key Certificates (leaf) [K]
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.1
- External CA Certificates (intermediate)[F]
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.2
- Instance CA Certificates (intermediate) [E]
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.3
- Endpoint Certificates (leaf)[H]
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.4
- Vehicle OEM Encryption Certificate (VehicleOEM.Enc.Cert)
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.5
- Vehicle OEM Signature Certificate (VehicleOEM.Sig.Cert)
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.6
- Device.Enc.Cert (optional as only the PK is sent in the trackKey request)
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.7
- Vehicle Intermediate Certificate
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.8
- Vehicle OEM CA Certificate [J]
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.9
- Vehicle OEM CA Certificate (Signed by Device OEM CA) [M] (optional as only used by some 4 implemenation)
  1.3.6.1.4.1.41577.5.10

Extensions with the above OIDs shall be marked as critical.

CCC digital key is widely adopted in automotive, and I think Automotive is one of the most important application areas of C509, please add the support if possible. If the authors decide to support it, I can propose the syntax of the extension value.

comments.body:
If any of these are important to use with C509 then we should prioritize to add them. Is C509 relevant for automotive industry?

( V2X probably not, based on IEEE )

issues.title: Editorial-type feedback comments from Brian Sipos
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/xwaKaVD2SJ3-uV0eh7WWYX3fp1Y/


1.	It is currently difficult to extract a full CDDL document for this
draft. Could one be extracted and added to the Github repo for reference? Or
some procedure for how we can extract a full, valid CDDL definition from the
markdown?
I did some copy-paste work to get this and am running into tool errors, it
seems like the 'time' rule is missing but maybe I'm extracting an
incomplete set..?
Also some reference CDDL like the 'oid' from RFC 9090 needs to be included
somehow; manually in a Github file is fine, but having a complete and
parseable CDDL document would be very valuable for users.

2.	The IANA sections which include what looks like a
dictionary-list-within-table-cells makes reading and interpreting the tables
difficult to me. Some IANA registries with many fields use a pure
dictionary-list representation to avoid having a table with large numbers of
columns.

3.	Also in IANA tables having multiple forms of the PKIX OIDs is
convenient but somewhat confusing that they are all just in the text without
specific labels or explanations. I can infer that they are 'name
(dotted-decimal) hex-binary' but being more explicit in the form and
explanation could be helpful (see no. 2 above about separating registry
fields).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Questions for @BrianSipos (and others having an opinion) related to the points above:

1.
@cabo made PR #215 and responded to the COSE mailing list: 
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/rEuV4sohR-0GZnuAj8becdXtwkU/
Does this solve the problem?


2.
Does this comment refer to all sections 9.3-9.11?

> Some IANA registries with many fields  ...

Do you have an RFC reference, or example of a preferred representation?

3.

What kind of explanations are you missing? Please give an example.

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
For 1, having a procedure is good and if possible having an already-extracted file in the source repo is more turnkey (not needing users of the CDDL to have the tools to properly extract) but not critical.

For 2, I've seen a couple of options for many-column registrations either as a definition list (as in [RFC 9052](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9052.html#section-11.3)) or a table (as in [RFC 9174](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9174.html#section-8.1)) for each registered code point. Both of these make the document more verbose, but also allow many columns to be present without a large width table.

For 3, just to be absolutely clear either before or after the table it would be good to explain how to interpret the format for the OIDs:
1. text name registered with IANA
2. dotted decimal OID with reference to [RFC 4512](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4512.html#section-1.4) (or something more recent if there is one)
3. Hex string of DER-encoded OID with reference to ITU-T X.690

issues.title: Avoid duplication about extensions in 3.3 and 3.1.10
issues.author: gselander

issues.title: Redefine COSE_C509
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
The current definition of COSE_C509

        COSE_C509 = C509Certificate / [ 2* C509Certificate ]

requires the handlers of the container to either decode the C509 contents itself or use a CBOR decoder to skip over the "C509Certificate" items (which likely contain deeply nested structure and is not a trivial activity [1] and not universally supported by CBOR libraries).

This is in contrast to the X.509 container, defined in RFC 9360 as

        COSE_X509 = bstr / [ 2*certs: bstr ]

which relieves the handler of that item of caring what are the exact contents of the contained bstr item(s).

Would it seem sensible to rework the C509 container as (something equivalent to) the following?

        COSE_C509 = C509CertData / [ 2* C509CertData ]
        C509CertData = bstr .cbor C509Certificate

This relieves the handler of the container from needing to decode the bstr items, but also allows an aware handler to validate the embedded CBOR item just as is required today. The expense is the bstr wrapper item, which for small-ish certificates would be an overhead of 2-3 bytes per certificate.

I understand that one of the main purposes of C509 is to reduce encoded size, but I think the current direct container contents also forces handlers to expend processing/memory resources to skip or decode the certificate contents even if that handler just passes the encoded certificate along to different entities/layers.

[1] https://github.com/laurencelundblade/QCBOR/blob/83c4af09d3752afa64ae66e2a3382192bf682541/inc/qcbor/qcbor_decode.h#L1014C1-L1014C28

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Source:
https://www.mail-archive.com/cose@ietf.org/msg04358.html

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
As suggested by Anders, this could just as well be defined as 
```
C509CertData = bstr .cborseq C509Certificate
```
To save the array head byte(s) because the signature is over the array front contents only. The only loss would be a decoder look-ahead hint for the number of extension items when decoding that section of data.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Is it necessary that each C509Certificate is byte string encoded? Why not

```
COSE_C509_ARRAY = C509Certificate / [ 2* C509Certificate ]
COSE_C509 = bstr .cborseq COSE_C509_ARRAY
```

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
There are benefits to having each cert as a separate byte string. Because thumbnails (`COSE_CertHash` and `c5t`) are computed from the `C509Certificate` bytes without decoding, given a byte string `C509CertData` I can compute and compare thumbnails without caring about the specific certificate contents. This enables caching of certificate validation results by users.

I can bring this up as a separate ticket, but it actually seems like `COSE_CertHash` is currently underdefined. I don't see any normative statements in the document about exactly what bytes are hashed to compute its value. Just the non-normative description "Hash of a C509Certificate".

If the hash really is over the entire `C509Certificate` structure including the array head then that steers toward the definition
```
C509CertData = bstr .cbor C509Certificate
```
If the hash is actually over `~C509Certificate` excluding the array head, then that steers toward the definition
```
C509CertData = bstr .cborseq C509Certificate
```
Because in either case the byte string contents are "whatever is used as input to the COSE_CertHash computation".

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Hi Brian,

Thanks for the clarification, then

```
COSE_C509 = C509CertData / [ 2* C509CertData ]
C509CertData = bstr .cborseq C509Certificate
```

and

`Hash of a ~C509Certificate`

seens appropriate.

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
Yes that is a good conclusion and will agree with the C509 TLS payload.

Side question about the TLS certificate type; does the existing `X509` type contain a certificate _chain_ and not restricted to a single certificate? If so, the C509 proposed type doesn't have parity in the TLS use.

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
I'm answering my own question, found in [RFC 8446](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8446#section-4.4.2) the statement:

>    certificate_list:  A sequence (chain) of CertificateEntry structures,
      each containing a single certificate and set of extensions.

So the TLS C509 use of `~C509Certificate` has exact parity with X509 type and having that same use for hash and for `C509CertData` bytes seems to have good consistency.

issues.title: Define `csrattrs`
issues.author: malishav
issues.body:
I would like to discuss whether it would make sense to define the CDDL of `application/csrattrs` in this document. 

`application/csrattrs` is defined in [Section 4.5 of RFC 7030](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7030#section-4.5) and the semantics is clarified in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc7030-csrattrs/.

The definition of `application/csrattrs` was brought up to `draft-ietf-ace-coap-est-oscore` in https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore/issues/34. However, the est-oscore document does not define any of the formats itself and relies for all CBOR formats on this document.

comments.author: gselander
cabo
comments.body:
I think this is the approximate equivalent:

~~~ cddl
CsrAttrs = [* AttrOrOID]

AttrOrOID = Oid / Attribute

Oid = ~oid
oid = #6.111(bstr) ; see RFC 9090

Attribute = $Attribute .within ([type, +value])

type = any
value = any
; (I don't know what type and value are.)

$Attribute /= [name: 1, + text]
$Attribute /= [datetime: 2, ~time]
~~~

Here is what the example generator produces:

~~~ cbor-diag
[h'616C62657363656E74', 
 [1, "hielaman"], 
 [2, -694], 
 [1, "oversound"]]
~~~

(The example generator doesn't know how an OID looks like, so it puts in a randomly chosen byte string.  
-694 probably is not a date I would have chosen for an example either.)

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
As far as I understand, it suffices with the three first lines from @cabo 

> CsrAttrs = [* AttrOrOID]
>
> AttrOrOID = ~oid / Attribute

The rest is already defined in the draft. The examples in the referenced documents seems to match.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Talking we Göran, the way forward is to specify a format based on TBSCertificateRequest. This is a similar solution as 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc7030-csrattrs-22#name-use-of-csr-templates

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Here is a suggestion that I think would work

```
C509CertificateRequestTemplate = [
   c509CertificateRequestType: int / null,
   subjectSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier / null,
   subject: NameTemplate,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier / null,
   subjectPublicKey: any / null,
   extensionsRequest: ExtensionsTemplate,
]

NameTemplate = [ * AttributeTemplate ]

AttributeTemplate = (( attributeType: int, attributeValue: text / null ) //
                     ( attributeType: ~oid, attributeValue: bytes / null ))

ExtensionsTemplate = [ * ExtensionTemplate ]

ExtensionTemplate = (( extensionID: int, extensionValue: any / null ) //
                     ( extensionID: ~oid, ? critical: bool,
                       extensionValue: bytes / null ))
```

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Yes, definitely helpful to propose CDDL!

The speed of development of C509 is dependent on input from the community. People are very welcome to contribute text, review, co-author, etc.. An alternative and welcome contribution is to make clear statements about what people want to see specified and in what context they are interested in using it. This could be in a github issue or an email to the COSE mailing list. At the end of the day, the COSE WG is deciding about content of drafts to progress, so it is always good to prepare the WG with expectations and intentions. Feel free to reach out if you have further comments or input.

issues.title: Media type for certificates by reference
issues.author: malishav
issues.body:
As just discussed during the IETF 122 Hackathon, we agreed on registering a new media type that indicates certificate by reference. This media type is to be used by `draft-ietf-ace-coap-est-oscore` draft during the negotiation in order to indicate support of the client for cert references. We discussed that it would make sense to have this media type indicate support for *any* kind of reference, i.e. irrespective whether it is `c5t` or `c5u`, as that would be equivalent from the point of view of a constrained device handling the certificate by reference (opaque binary blob of data without access to the actual certificate).

See https://github.com/ace-wg/est-oscore/issues/69

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Does this refer to both Media type and Content format?

comments.author: malishav
comments.body:
> Does this refer to both Media type and Content format?

To my understanding, it does refer to both.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
@malishav Please look at #231 with proposed specifications of content formats and media types (where necessary). The scope here is credentials by reference as defined in this specification, i.e. `c5b`, `c5c`, `c5u` and `c5t` (currently with the addition of `x5t`, since the media type for COSE_CertHash is defined in this document but this is pending the review from other authors and may be taken out). The remaining content formats does not really belong to this document and can be defined analogously in `draft-ietf-ace-coap-est-oscore`.

We didn't find any good solution for a media type indicating _any_ credential by reference, and propose that this is addressed with an appropriate CoAP option enabling the enumeration of acceptable media types. The CoAP Accept option is not repeatable and expect a single Content-Format. However,  the Multi-Valued Accept Option in
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-fossati-core-parametrized-cf
seems to address this case. Perhaps that draft, or just that option, can be resurrected for this purpose?

Please let us know if we can close this issue.

pulls.title: Updates to the CBOR profile structure in CDDL
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body:
The general requirement for CBOR "compression" profiles is a canonical de-composition and re-composition so that:

* the CBOR data item in motion is as small as (feasible) possible,
* signature validation works on the recomposing side, and
* a wide range of TLS profile certificates can be processed.

The proposal in this PR is intended to be a basis for discussion of the following first batch of topics:

* a self-sustaining consistent CDDL spec,
* different handling of the hierarchical names subject and issuer,
* retaining directoryString types and also AI5,
* retaining potential alg parameters,
* simplified enumeration for mandatory TLS profile extensions, and
* retaining arbitrary extensions.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
In 

> 3.4. COSE Header Parameters

we state that

> The formatting and processing for c5b, c5c, and c5t, and c5u, defined in Table 1 are similar to x5bag, x5chain, x5t, x5u defined in [RFC9360] except that the certificates are C509 instead of DER encoded X.509 and uses a COSE_C509 structure instead of COSE_X509. 

And analogously to [application/cose-x509](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/application/cose-x509) we define:

> The content is a COSE_C509 item served with the application/cose-c509 content format.

(It had better be "media type" instead of "content format", but that's not relevant here.)
 
The use of pkcs10 in application/cose-c509-pkcs10 is following [application/pkcs10](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/application/pkcs10) which does not use "csr". So a more consequential name would be application/c509-pkcs10 

If we change from application/cose-c509 to application/c509- ..., should we then also change the structure from COSE_C509 to just C509?

pulls.body: Fixes #168.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
* Self-signed is not mentioned.
* Not clear to me if this is normative, e.g. if iss == sub then iss = null.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
WIth this proposed text:
> If the 'issuer' field is identical to 'subject' field it is encoded as CBOR null.

the encoding is normative and deterministic, but increases code complexity.

The previous formulation:
> If the 'issuer' field is the CBOR simple value null then 'issuer' is identical to 'subject'.

allows the 'issuer' field to be be identical to the 'subject' field in the C509 and is non-deterministic, but does not have to increase code complexity.

pulls.title: Add explanation for and optional nature of bundleEID otherName
pulls.author: BrianSipos
pulls.body: The phrasing here is draft but the intention is to allow a c509 processor to use this compressed form when Bundle EIDs can be processed (by relying parties in the network) but general translating c509 processors can use the otherName code point with a blind by-value copy (of a text URI) and lose out on the possible compression.

pulls.title: Simplification of 'name'
pulls.author: gselander
pulls.body:
Addresses #172. For discussion.

* Makes use of the CBOR tag for MAC addresses which didn't exist at the time when the original text was written.

* Does not make use of the CBOR tags for IPv4/v6 addresses, but removes the arbitrary prefix '00' for encoding of byte strings, since we can now distinguish from EUI-64 by above.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
@cabo noted on the COSE list that CBOR tag 23 encodes upper case hex text strings. This is a possible completeness addition, but makes processing slightly more complicated, contradicting the original intent with this PR. 

Rule to add: 
 *If the text string has an even length {{{≥}}} 2 and contains only the symbols '0'–'9' or 'A'–'H', it is encoded as  a CBOR tagged byte string using the CBOR tag 23, see {{Section 3.4.5.2 of RFC8949}}.
 

Edit: Adding just this rule leads to non-deterministic encoding of hex strings containing only digits. It is possible to redefine the rule for lower case hex to make the encoding deterministic (e.g. specifying which encoding to use for only digits) but then it becomes more complicated. 

I think the possibility to compactly encode pure hex names is useful and it reduces the size of certs used in DRIP by at least 10%, but I don't think we need to specify encoding for both lower and upper case.

pulls.title: Redefine COSE_C509
pulls.author: gselander
pulls.body: New definitions of COSE-C509 and how to hash C509 certificates. Addresses #222.

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
This captures the intent. It would be good if there was a normative statement about the hash input data being the unwrapped CBOR sequence just to be clear. The current table text seems non-normative and I can see it being misread or misinterpreted.

It could also be good to have an informative statement somewhere that the hash input is exactly the same as the `C509CertData` contained byte string and the same as the TLS certificate bytes just to make that clear.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
@BrianSipos Thanks for reviewing. 

>  It would be good if there was a normative statement about the hash input data being the unwrapped CBOR sequence just to be clear. The current table text seems non-normative and I can see it being misread or misinterpreted.

I tried to address this by adding text saying the same thing as the content of the table. Since this is a definition I don't think it is necessary with normative text as in BCP 14. Please have a look.

> It could also be good to have an informative statement somewhere that the hash input is exactly the same as the C509CertData contained byte string and the same as the TLS certificate bytes just to make that clear.

I didn't understand this. In the current text, the input to the hash function is the unwrapped CBOR sequence ~C509Certificate, hence not the CBOR bstr wrapped CBOR sequence which is C509CertData. Is there some misunderstanding here?

comments.author: BrianSipos
comments.body:
> Is there some misunderstanding here?

No, this was poor phrasing on my part. Here is a suggestion for in-document text to clarify the behavior and the intent.

"The data used for the c5t parameter hash input is identical to the data contained within a `C509CertData` byte string of the c5b and c5c parameters and identical to the data contained within a TLS `cert_data` associated with type TBD5."

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
@BrianSipos Here is another attempt, have a look. 

I did not add anything about TLS `cert_data` since there is already some text in 9.18 - is that sufficient or is there something that needs to be added?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I don't see how this works. Refers to the CDDL 'Attributes' which I don't think is related to this. This cannot be used to request signature algorithms. 

Mixing everything together in the same oid space does not fit well with the design choices made in C509.

I suggest we state that CSR Attributes are out of scope...

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
To support this I think we would need a CSRAttribute table, where each entry is something like
int, ? any
then everything would need to be reregistered there.

A more c509 way would be to change the format. If I understand correctly the information is

-   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,

-   issuerSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   
 -  RFC2985 Attributes
 
 - extensionsRequest: Extensions,

Just resusing

TBSCertificateRequest = (
   c509CertificateRequestType: int,
   subjectSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   extensionRequest: Extensions,
)

Seems perfect....

Do we still like the hack of encoding challengePassword as an extension?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I don't think "CSR Attributes" is the right name. challengePassword is a CRS attribute. This seems EST related, and not related to any of the two other kinds of attributes.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I suggest we just reuse TBSCertificateRequest for EST attributes.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Here is a suggestion that I think would work

```
C509CertificateRequestTemplate = [
   c509CertificateRequestType: int / null,
   subjectSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier / null,
   subject: NameTemplate,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier / null,
   subjectPublicKey: any / null,
   extensionsRequest: ExtensionsTemplate,
]

NameTemplate = [ * AttributeTemplate ]

AttributeTemplate = (( attributeType: int, attributeValue: text / null ) //
                     ( attributeType: ~oid, attributeValue: bytes / null ))

ExtensionsTemplate = [ * ExtensionTemplate ]

ExtensionTemplate = (( extensionID: int, extensionValue: any / null ) //
                     ( extensionID: ~oid, ? critical: bool,
                       extensionValue: bytes / null ))
```

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
C509CertificateRequestTemplate is based on 509CertificateRequest but without the subjectSignatureValue field. C509CertificateRequest looks like this

```
C509CertificateRequest = [
  c509CertificateRequestType: int,
   subjectSignatureAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subject: Name,
   subjectPublicKeyAlgorithm: AlgorithmIdentifier,
   subjectPublicKey: any,
   extensionsRequest: Extensions,
   subjectSignatureValue: any,
]

Name = [ * Attribute ] / text / bytes

Attribute = (( attributeType: int, attributeValue: text ) //
             ( attributeType: ~oid, attributeValue: bytes ))

Extensions = [ * Extension ] / int

Extension = (( extensionID: int, extensionValue: any ) //
             ( extensionID: ~oid, ? critical: true,
              extensionValue: bytes ))
```

Name and Extensions needws changes.
